message.content:
cs.PL, cs.AR, cs.SE, cs.SY, cs.LG

This paper discusses a novel approach to building compiler infrastructure that addresses software fragmentation, improves compilation for heterogeneous hardware, and reduces the cost of building domain-specific compilers. These topics are relevant to several sub-categories of computer science, but the focus on compiler infrastructure and programming languages suggests that cs.PL (Programming Languages) is the most likely category. The paper also discusses optimization and system design, which are relevant to cs.AR (Architecture) and cs.SY (Systems and Control), respectively. The discussion of MLIR as a research artifact and its potential impact on future programming languages and computer architecture suggests that cs.LG (Machine Learning) may also be a relevant category. Finally, the paper emphasizes the importance of extensibility and evolution, which suggests that cs.SE (Software Engineering) may also be a relevant category.
